title: Getting Started
text: chinadevfin2 primarily data package enabling efficient method working AidData’s Global Chinese Development Finance Dataset, Version 2.0 (GCDF 2.0) R. chinadevfin2is designed eliminate two time-consuming pain-points working datasets: Data import & cleaning: chinadevfin2 package loads dataset, variables already formatted correct data types. Users can begin meaningful analysis just lines code. Country name standardization: default, chinafindev2 package loads dataset standardized country names iso3c codes. allows users easily join data sourced elsewhere, example income groups, custom country grouping, macroeconomic data, without worrying whether whether dataset uses different versions country’s name (e.g. Philippines Philippines).

title: Getting Started
text: [get_gcdf2_dataset()] loads GCDF 2.0 dataset standarized country names. Since data already cleaned, can start interesting analysis right way. countries largest receipients Chinese development finance? can answer finding sum commitments (constant 2017 USD).
code: library(chinadevfin2) # load the package library(dplyr) # for data analysis   # get the dataset, with standardized country names committments_by_country <- get_gcdf2_dataset() |>    # See `recommended_for_aggregates` in the gcdf2_data_dictionary to learn more about this.    filter(recommended_for_aggregates == "Yes") |>   # filter out regional projects    filter(country_or_regional == "country") |>   # for each country   group_by(country_name, iso3c) |>    # Find the sum in constant 2017 USD   summarize(total_commitments_bn = sum(amount_constant_usd2017, na.rm = TRUE)/10^9) |>    # ungroup to avoid strange side effects of grouped tibbles   ungroup() |>    # arrange by descending order   arrange(total_commitments_bn |> desc())  committments_by_country #> # A tibble: 142 × 3 #>    country_name iso3c total_commitments_bn #>    <chr>        <chr>                <dbl> #>  1 Russia       RUS                  125.  #>  2 Venezuela    VEN                   91.1 #>  3 Angola       AGO                   52.7 #>  4 Kazakhstan   KAZ                   42.3 #>  5 Brazil       BRA                   41.5 #>  6 Indonesia    IDN                   34.9 #>  7 Pakistan     PAK                   34.6 #>  8 Vietnam      VNM                   18.5 #>  9 Iran         IRN                   17.1 #> 10 Ecuador      ECU                   16.9 #> # ℹ 132 more rows

title: Getting Started
text: Standardized country names makes easy add data sources. ’s simple example. , calculated total commitments per country 2000-2017 period. doesn’t give us much perspective large commitments context country’s economy. One way can looking size commitments versus relevant denominator, like population economy size. , ’ll get data World Bank’s API using wbstats R package. AidData’s commitments displayed constant 2017 USD, ’ll get countries’ 2017 USD GDP. handful countries, Venezuela, GDP data earlier years, ’ll get recent non-empty value.

title: Getting Started
code: # load the wbstats R package to access World Bank data library(wbstats)  # get USD GDP from 2017, to align with GCDF 2.0's reporting figures in 2017 USD. wb_gdp_usd_2017 <- wb_data(indicator = c("gdp_usd_2017" = "NY.GDP.MKTP.CD"),                            start_date = 2017,                            end_date = 2017) |>    select(iso3c, gdp_usd_2017)  # Venezuela (a large recipient of Chinese lending) only reported GDP data through 2014. This is true for a small handful of other countries such as Eritrea and South Sudan too.  For those, we will get the most recent non-empty value (`mnrev`)  wb_gdp_usd_mrnev <- wb_data(indicator = c("gdp_usd_mrnev" = "NY.GDP.MKTP.CD"),                            mrnev = 1) |>    select(iso3c, gdp_usd_mrnev)  # combine the datasets together to get 2017 GDP where available, but use the most recent non-empty (`mnrev`) value where 2017 data is not available.  wb_gdp_usd_2017_or_mrnev <- wb_gdp_usd_2017 |>    left_join(wb_gdp_usd_mrnev, by = "iso3c") |>    mutate(gdp_usd_2017_or_mrnev = if_else(is.na(gdp_usd_2017),                                  true = gdp_usd_mrnev,                                 false = gdp_usd_2017),          # change the scale to billions of USD, in line with commitments          gdp_usd_2017_or_mrnev_bn = gdp_usd_2017_or_mrnev/10^9) |>    select(iso3c, gdp_usd_2017_or_mrnev_bn)  wb_gdp_usd_2017_or_mrnev #> # A tibble: 217 × 2 #>    iso3c gdp_usd_2017_or_mrnev_bn #>    <chr>                    <dbl> #>  1 ABW                      3.09  #>  2 AFG                     18.9   #>  3 AGO                     69.0   #>  4 ALB                     13.0   #>  5 AND                      3.00  #>  6 ARE                    391.    #>  7 ARG                    644.    #>  8 ARM                     11.5   #>  9 ASM                      0.612 #> 10 ATG                      1.47  #> # ℹ 207 more rows

what: Attach the data and do cool things
title: Getting Started
text: Now ’ll add GDP data committments_by_country tibble created , calculate commitments percent 2017 (recently available) GDP. interesting. One extreme humility GDP measurements small & lower income countries. Nevertheless, gives us useful context large Chinese development finance committments betwee 2000-2017 many smaller poorer countries.
code: committments_by_country |>    # join the two datasets by iso3c codes   left_join(wb_gdp_usd_2017_or_mrnev, by = "iso3c") |>    # calculate the value of total commitments as a percentage of GDP   mutate(commitments_pct_gdp = total_commitments_bn/gdp_usd_2017_or_mrnev_bn * 100) |>    # remove the iso3c column so the rest of the columns will be visible   select(-iso3c) |>    # arrange the output in descending order by commitments as percent of GDP   arrange(commitments_pct_gdp |> desc())  #> # A tibble: 142 × 4 #>    country_name  total_commitments_bn gdp_usd_2017_or_mrne…¹ commitments_pct_gdp #>    <chr>                        <dbl>                  <dbl>               <dbl> #>  1 Marshall Isl…                3.21                   0.213              1508.  #>  2 Laos                        14.5                   17.1                  85.0 #>  3 Angola                      52.7                   69.0                  76.5 #>  4 Tonga                        0.326                  0.460                70.9 #>  5 Sierra Leone                 2.40                   3.72                 64.5 #>  6 Djibouti                     1.77                   2.76                 64.2 #>  7 Congo - Braz…                6.61                  11.1                  59.6 #>  8 Eritrea                      1.00                   2.07                 48.6 #>  9 Samoa                        0.406                  0.885                45.9 #> 10 Cambodia                    10.0                   22.2                  45.3 #> # ℹ 132 more rows #> # ℹ abbreviated name: ¹​gdp_usd_2017_or_mrnev_bn

title: Getting Started
text: AidData’s summary dataset: AidData’s Global Chinese Development Finance Dataset, Version 2.0. records known universe projects (development, commercial, representational intent) supported official financial -kind commitments (pledges) China 2000-2017, implementation details covering 22-year period (2000-2021). dataset captures 13,427 projects worth $843 billion financed 300 Chinese government institutions state-owned entities across 165 countries every major region world. AidData systematically collected quality-assured projects dataset using 2.0 version Tracking Underreported Financial Flows (TUFF) methodology. Please see AidData’s dataset website full citation details. unfamiliar dataset, following resources great place start: AidData - Policy Report: Banking Belt Road: Insights new global dataset 13,427 Chinese development projects AidData - Methodology: Tracking Underreported Financial Flows (TUFF) methodology, 2.0. AidData - Dataset Website: Global Chinese Development Finance Dataset, Version 2.0

title: Getting Started
text: dataset’s data dictionary, definitions 70 variables, available object gcdf2_data_dictionary. Let’s use reactable package make table explore data definitions. ’s ’ll find gcdf2_data_dictionary: column_name: name column gcdf2_dataset. snake_case version name given variable AidData displayed field name, easier work R. column_class: data type variable, numeric, character, Date. field_name: original name variable given AidData. description: detailed definition variable. Take time. ’s lot .
code: # load reactable library to make pretty tables library(reactable)  gcdf2_data_dictionary |>    reactable(searchable = TRUE,             sortable = TRUE,             filterable = TRUE,             bordered = TRUE,             defaultPageSize = 3,             columns = list(               column_class = colDef(minWidth = 65),               description = colDef(minWidth = 250)             )             )

title: Getting Started
text: examples , found meaning dataset creating aggregates. GCDF 2.0 dataset’s recommended_for_aggregates variable identifies projects AidData recommends used creating data aggregates. example , use filter(recommended_for_aggregates == "Yes") part dplyr pipeline creating aggregates. AidData’s full explanation data dictionary: field identifies projects AidData recommends including analysis requires aggregation projects supported official financial (-kind) commitments China, including analysis monetary amounts project counts. useful identifying formally approved, active, completed Chinese government-financed projects – excluding cancelled projects, suspended projects, projects never reached formal approval (official commitment) stage. field set “Yes” projects status designation Pipeline: Commitment, Implementation, Completion also designated umbrella agreements. set “” cancelled projects, suspended projects, projects never reached official commitment stage (.e. projects status designation Pipeline: Pledge, Suspended, Cancelled). Additionally, avoid double-counting, field set “” umbrella agreements. information umbrella agreements, see description “Umbrella” field file. Also, note projects “Recommended Aggregates” value “True” identify financial transaction value (since transactions difficult monetize, -kind donations, technical assistance, scholarships, training activities).

code: # install the `devtools` package if not yet installed # install.packages("devtools")  # install chinadevfin2 from GitHub devtools::install_github("t-emery/chinadevfin2")

title: An R Package for AidData's Global Chinese Development Finance 2.0 Dataset
text: core initial functionality chinadevfin2 load GCDF 2.0 dataset tibble using get_gcdf2_dataset(): gcdf2_data_dictionary contains AidData’s detailed data definitions GCDF 2.0 variables: makes easy find actionable insights quickly. Let’s look growth concessional versus non-concessional lending years covered dataset (2000-2017). Now can use ggplot2 make data visualization:
code: # load the chinadevfin2 library library(chinadevfin2) library(tidyverse) #> ── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ── #> ✔ dplyr     1.1.2     ✔ readr     2.1.4 #> ✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.0 #> ✔ ggplot2   3.4.2     ✔ tibble    3.2.1 #> ✔ lubridate 1.9.2     ✔ tidyr     1.3.0 #> ✔ purrr     1.0.1      #> ── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ── #> ✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter() #> ✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag() #> ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors  # Load the GCDF 2.0 dataset as a tibble, with standardized country names added at the beginning. get_gcdf2_dataset() #> # A tibble: 13,427 × 73 #>    country_name iso3c country_or_regional aid_data_tuff_project_id #>    <chr>        <chr> <chr>                                  <dbl> #>  1 Afghanistan  AFG   country                                53631 #>  2 Afghanistan  AFG   country                                53632 #>  3 Afghanistan  AFG   country                                53633 #>  4 Afghanistan  AFG   country                                53634 #>  5 Afghanistan  AFG   country                                53636 #>  6 Afghanistan  AFG   country                                53637 #>  7 Afghanistan  AFG   country                                53644 #>  8 Afghanistan  AFG   country                                53999 #>  9 Afghanistan  AFG   country                                54396 #> 10 Afghanistan  AFG   country                                56587 #> # ℹ 13,417 more rows #> # ℹ 69 more variables: recommended_for_aggregates <chr>, umbrella <chr>, #> #   financier_country <chr>, recipient <chr>, recipient_region <chr>, #> #   commitment_year <dbl>, commitment_year_estimated <chr>, #> #   implementation_start_year <dbl>, completion_year <dbl>, title <chr>, #> #   description <chr>, staff_comments <chr>, status <chr>, intent <chr>, #> #   flow_type <chr>, concessional <chr>, flow_class <chr>, sector_code <dbl>, … # Load the GCDF 2.0 data dictionary as a tibble gcdf2_data_dictionary #> # A tibble: 70 × 4 #>    column_name                column_class field_name                description #>    <chr>                      <chr>        <chr>                     <chr>       #>  1 aid_data_tuff_project_id   numeric      AidData TUFF Project ID   "This fiel… #>  2 recommended_for_aggregates character    Recommended For Aggregat… "This fiel… #>  3 umbrella                   character    Umbrella                  "This fiel… #>  4 financier_country          character    Financier Country         "This fiel… #>  5 recipient                  character    Recipient                 "This fiel… #>  6 recipient_region           character    Recipient Region          "This fiel… #>  7 commitment_year            numeric      Commitment Year           "This fiel… #>  8 commitment_year_estimated  character    Commitment Year Estimated "For proje… #>  9 implementation_start_year  numeric      Implementation Start Year "This fiel… #> 10 completion_year            numeric      Completion Year           "This fiel… #> # ℹ 60 more rows concessional_vs_non_concenssional <- get_gcdf2_dataset() |>    # See `recommended_for_aggregates` in the gcdf2_data_dictionary to learn more about this.    filter(recommended_for_aggregates == "Yes") |>    # Group by the commitment year and whether the loand is concessional   group_by(commitment_year, concessional) |>    # Find the sum by year and concessionality type in constant 2017 USD   summarize(commitments = sum(amount_constant_usd2017, na.rm = TRUE)) |>    # ungroup to avoid strange side effects of grouped tibbles   ungroup() |>    # make prettier names for a chart or table   mutate(label_for_chart = case_when(concessional=="Yes" ~ "Concessional",                                      concessional=="No" ~ "Non-Concessional",                                      concessional=="Vague" ~ "Unclear",                                      )) #> `summarise()` has grouped output by 'commitment_year'. You can override using #> the `.groups` argument.  concessional_vs_non_concenssional #> # A tibble: 54 × 4 #>    commitment_year concessional commitments label_for_chart  #>              <dbl> <chr>              <dbl> <chr>            #>  1            2000 No             35730163. Non-Concessional #>  2            2000 Vague        1515226164. Unclear          #>  3            2000 Yes          2068689349. Concessional     #>  4            2001 No            197609156. Non-Concessional #>  5            2001 Vague        3876972191. Unclear          #>  6            2001 Yes          4139903249. Concessional     #>  7            2002 No           1303999712. Non-Concessional #>  8            2002 Vague        1524781321. Unclear          #>  9            2002 Yes          3212037121. Concessional     #> 10            2003 No            659706286. Non-Concessional #> # ℹ 44 more rows concessional_vs_non_concenssional |>    ggplot(aes(x = commitment_year, y = commitments, fill = label_for_chart)) +   geom_bar(stat = "identity") +   scale_fill_brewer(palette = "Blues") +   theme_minimal(base_size = 14) +   scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::label_dollar(suffix = " bn", scale = 1/10^9, accuracy = 1)) +   labs(title = "Chinese Development Finance Loan Commitments",        subtitle = "chinadevfin2: from ideas to actionable insights, quickly",        x = "Commitment Year",        y = "Commitments (2017 Constant USD)",        fill = "",        caption = "Data: AidData's Global Chinese Development Finance Dataset, 2.0\nUsing the chinadevfin2 R package") +   theme(legend.position="top")

title: Standardized Country Names — gcdf2_standardized_countrynames
text: tibble providing standardized country names, iso3c codes, column filter country-specific regional projects. Country names standardized using countrycode::countryname().

title: Standardized Country Names — gcdf2_standardized_countrynames
Standardized Country Names — gcdf2_standardized_countrynames
text: tibble 152 rows 4 variables: recipient chr loan recipient listed recipient column gcdf2_dataset. See gcdf2_data_dictionary details. country_name chr standardized country name provided countrycode::countryname(). project regional, region listed recipient used. iso3c chr iso3c country code can helpful joining country features. Projects recipient region NA values. country_or_regional chr column allow filtering country-based lending regional lending.

what: Load the AidData Global Chinese Development Finance 2.0 Dataset — get_gcdf2_dataset
title: Load the AidData Global Chinese Development Finance 2.0 Dataset — get_gcdf2_dataset
text: get_gcdf2_dataset() makes easy load AidData's Global Chinese Development Finance Dataset, Version 2.0 (GCDF 2.0). default, function adds standardized country names make easier merge datasets.  standardized country names described documentation gcdf2_standardized_countrynames. Setting standardized_countrynames = FALSE equivalent simply calling gcdf2_dataset data object.  data definitions available gcdf2_data_dictionary.

title: Load the AidData Global Chinese Development Finance 2.0 Dataset — get_gcdf2_dataset
Load the AidData Global Chinese Development Finance 2.0 Dataset — get_gcdf2_dataset
text: standardized_countrynames set TRUE default, argument attaches standardized country names make easier join dataset datasets.

title: Load the AidData Global Chinese Development Finance 2.0 Dataset — get_gcdf2_dataset
text: get_gcdf2_dataset() returns tibble 13,427 observations.

code: # returns the GCDF 2.0 dataset, with standardized country names get_gcdf2_dataset() #> # A tibble: 13,427 × 73 #>    country_name iso3c country_or_regional aid_data_tuff_project_id #>    <chr>        <chr> <chr>                                  <dbl> #>  1 Afghanistan  AFG   country                                53631 #>  2 Afghanistan  AFG   country                                53632 #>  3 Afghanistan  AFG   country                                53633 #>  4 Afghanistan  AFG   country                                53634 #>  5 Afghanistan  AFG   country                                53636 #>  6 Afghanistan  AFG   country                                53637 #>  7 Afghanistan  AFG   country                                53644 #>  8 Afghanistan  AFG   country                                53999 #>  9 Afghanistan  AFG   country                                54396 #> 10 Afghanistan  AFG   country                                56587 #> # ℹ 13,417 more rows #> # ℹ 69 more variables: recommended_for_aggregates <chr>, umbrella <chr>, #> #   financier_country <chr>, recipient <chr>, recipient_region <chr>, #> #   commitment_year <dbl>, commitment_year_estimated <chr>, #> #   implementation_start_year <dbl>, completion_year <dbl>, title <chr>, #> #   description <chr>, staff_comments <chr>, status <chr>, intent <chr>, #> #   flow_type <chr>, concessional <chr>, flow_class <chr>, sector_code <dbl>, …  # returns the GCDF 2.0 dataset as-is. get_gcdf2_dataset(standardized_countrynames = FALSE) #> # A tibble: 13,427 × 70 #>    aid_data_tuff_project_id recommended_for_aggrega…¹ umbrella financier_country #>                       <dbl> <chr>                     <chr>    <chr>             #>  1                    53631 Yes                       No       China (People's … #>  2                    53632 Yes                       No       China (People's … #>  3                    53633 Yes                       No       China (People's … #>  4                    53634 Yes                       No       China (People's … #>  5                    53636 Yes                       No       China (People's … #>  6                    53637 Yes                       No       China (People's … #>  7                    53644 Yes                       No       China (People's … #>  8                    53999 Yes                       No       China (People's … #>  9                    54396 No                        No       China (People's … #> 10                    56587 Yes                       No       China (People's … #> #
